These programs are voluntary and anonymous, meaning people can turn in guns without fear of legal repercussions. The collected weapons are then destroyed or removed from circulation, reducing the number of guns in the community.

Now, when it comes to whether they help reduce gun violence—absolutely, they do. Beyond the statistics, gun buybacks also send a powerful message: that communities are committed to reducing violence and saving lives. They create a tangible opportunity to make neighborhoods safer, especially for children and vulnerable populations who are most affected by gun violence.

So yes, gun buyback programs are not only effective—they're essential tools in our effort to build safer, healthier communities.
